take somebody/something ↔ out.translati: to take someone as your guest to a restaurant, cinema, club etc
We’re taking my folks out for a meal next week.
to make a financial or legal arrangement with a bank, company, law court etc
Before taking a loan out, calculate your monthly outgoings.
to get money from your bank account
How much would you like to take out?
to borrow books from a library
You can take out six books at a time.
to kill someone or destroy something
The building was taken out by a bomb.
to arrange to get something officially, especially from an insurance company or a court of law
I’m thinking of taking out a life insurance policy.
If discounting took place without the publishers’ permission, they would take out an injunction  (=ask a court of law to give an order) to prevent it.
when investors who provided the capital to start a new business sell shares in the business once it has become successful
